Does anyone here have android development experience?

message.div: how deep an experience do you want?
i wrote apps that did side channel communication attacks on android a couple of months ago

div.span: I'm encountering memory issues with image display.
how are you drawing the image?
how big is the image you're loading, and what kind of android device are you using?
It displays when it's first run, but the memory runs out when the orientation changes.
that's odd, i've never had imageview give me any issues with memory
dalvik has a pretty aggressive garbage collector
I'm guessing that it's not freeing memory when it re-draws views
do you have the exact error it gives up?
yeah, well have you tried killing that imageview
and making a new one with the new orientation
so that it's forced to garbagecollect the old one
i'm guessing it has to create a new texture for the rotated one
and it puts that in the memory before getting rid of the old one
I assumed that it's done automatically.
The error is Bitmap Size Exceeds VM Memory Budget
the dalvik collector takes care of the rest
so get rid of them on the layout
then you can tell the garbagecollector that you don't want it any more by either replacing your variable with another ImageView
you can also join the android dev mailing list and ask it there if you want
BitmapFactory has better control over memory usage

chris left the room (quit: Quit: leaving).
what's a good price these days for a decent gaming pc?
depends on how BA you want it to be
I'm very interested in the new i7 2600K cpus
but if I want that, I really should get a Z68 mobo, which adds to cost.
how much more are you looking at
and if I'm getting a Z68, I really should get an SSD drive so that I can use the caching feature
you'll probably be using the computer for at least 5 years
right now what I have is priced to over $1300.
I would buy the cheapest possible.
would buy the most expensive possible
i've bought all parts from NewEgg for the past 8 or so years
but now they're not always the cheapest anymore....
you should buy it from amazon
but thats 16GB memory, PCI SSD drive...
new components decrease in value very fast. so buying cheap components that do not change value very fast is your best bet.
calvinl: you raise a good point, amazon should have the stuff...
plus moore's law is gonna kick your ass
you shouldn't buy the new stuff, since it'll depreciate in value so fast
unless he's looking to sell it at some point, value depreciation isn't too relevant
For instance, a 2 TB harddrive costs $70, while two years ago with $70 you could hardly buy a 250 GB drive...
save your money to buy that 10 TB drive a few years later is always a good idea
but I want to play video games *now*, not in a few years
the point is that this is not an investment.
i hear chrome laptops have angry birds. thats a video game...
at least not one that could win...if you buy expensive parts
unless you're doing a lot of graphic development
then the stuff 2 yearas ago should be more than enough
Listen, there's a new eldar scrolls game coming out in November. And if I'm not playing it on the highest settings enjoyably, then i've done something wrong.
actually doing graphic development takes very cheap computers...renderings are always done on rendering farms anyway..
I signed up for amazon student...it does not appear useful when I am buying more exotic items.. = =||
i meant an investment in terms of utility not really in terms of resale value
okay, so my cart with Amazon for the same set of items it $1394, compared to $1327 on newegg. But, minus 10%...
yeah, got responses from about 10 people so far kitching
I dont think it works that way...your discount code is capped..
note: it's not 10% off everything, only 10% off eligible stuff
the 10% off only applies to the first $1000 each year fyi
